verses.text: Then David said, 'This is the house of the LORD God, and this is the altar of burnt offering for Israel.'
verses.comment: David identifies the exact spot for God's dwelling and altar, setting a foundation for central worship. This establishes continuity from temporary tabernacle to a permanent temple, prefiguring the unity and sacramental worship to come.

verses.text: David commanded to gather the foreigners who were in the land of Israel, and he appointed stonecutters to prepare dressed stones for building the house of God.
verses.comment: Foreigners, rather than native Israelites, are enlisted for the preparation work, reflecting both practical wisdom and the gathering of all peoples to serve God's purposes.

verses.text: David prepared iron in abundance for nails for the doors of the gates and joins, and bronze in great quantity without weighing,
verses.comment: The lavish provision of materials shows a dedication to excellence in worship, foreshadowing the importance of sacred space and the care given to it.

verses.text: and cedar logs beyond number, for the Sidonians and Tyrians brought cedar wood in abundance to David.
verses.comment: Sidonian and Tyrian contributions highlight the international cooperation in building God's house, pointing ahead to the universal participation in God's saving plan.

verses.text: David said, 'Solomon my son is young and inexperienced, and the house to be built for the LORD must be exceedingly great, famous and glorious throughout all lands. Therefore, I will make preparations for it.' So David provided large quantities before his death.
verses.comment: David’s foresight demonstrates responsible shepherding, laying up treasure for the future temple. The emphasis on the temple’s glory hints at the splendor of divine worship instituted for all nations.

verses.text: Then he called for Solomon his son and charged him to build a house for the LORD God of Israel.
verses.comment: The passing of duty from father to son links God’s covenant faithfulness with succession, foreshadowing apostolic succession in spiritual leadership.

verses.text: David said to Solomon, 'My son, I intended to build a house to the name of the LORD my God,
verses.comment: Although David desires to build, he recognizes God’s sovereignty in decision-making, presenting a model for humility and obedience to divine guidance.

verses.text: but the word of the LORD came to me, saying, ‘You have shed much blood and waged great wars. You shall not build a house for my name, because you have shed much blood before me on the earth.’
verses.comment: God’s restriction respects the holiness of the temple, reserved for peace, suggesting the importance of purity in the service of God.

verses.text: 'Behold, a son shall be born to you, who shall be a man of rest. I will give him rest from all his enemies. His name shall be Solomon, and I will give peace and quiet to Israel during his days.'
verses.comment: The promise of a 'man of rest' alludes to messianic peace and fulfillment, foreshadowing Christ, the true bringer of peace (see Isa. 9:6).

verses.text: 'He shall build a house for my name. He shall be my son, and I will be his father. I will establish his royal throne over Israel forever.'
verses.comment: The father-son language anticipates the mystery of God the Father and the Son. The promise of an everlasting throne finds ultimate fulfillment in Christ (see Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: 'Now, my son, may the LORD be with you, that you may prosper and build the house of the LORD your God, as he has spoken concerning you.'
verses.comment: David blesses Solomon, emphasizing divine support as key to true establishment—a theme later echoed in apostolic commissioning.

verses.text: 'May the LORD give you wisdom and understanding when he puts you in charge of Israel, so that you may keep the law of the LORD your God.'
verses.comment: David prays for wisdom—a virtue inseparable from obedience to God’s law, an early model of seeking both knowledge and submission to divine authority.

verses.text: 'You will succeed if you are careful to observe the decrees and laws that the LORD gave Moses for Israel. Be strong and courageous; do not fear or be dismayed.'
verses.comment: Solomon is charged to be firm and attentive in fulfilling divine law—a timeless principle for leaders and discipleship. 'Be strong and courageous' repeats the call given to Joshua, showing continuity in God’s dealings.

verses.text: 'Now, look, with great effort I have provided for the house of the LORD: one hundred thousand talents of gold, one million talents of silver, bronze and iron beyond weighing, for there is so much; I have also provided timber and stone, and you may add to them.'
verses.comment: The generous offering models sacrificial giving for the worship of God. David demonstrates the value and honor given to worship and sacred things.

verses.text: 'You have an abundance of workmen: stonecutters, masons, carpenters, and all kinds of skilled people for every kind of work.'
verses.comment: The skills and unity of the workers point toward the harmony of gifts within the unified body of believers, a spiritual house being built in the New Covenant.

verses.text: 'You have gold, silver, bronze, and iron beyond number. Arise and begin the work, and may the LORD be with you.'
verses.comment: The call to action, supported by divine presence, stresses cooperation in achieving God’s purposes, a pattern for both leadership and community.

verses.text: David also commanded all the leaders of Israel to help Solomon his son,
verses.comment: The communal support for Solomon emphasizes unity of leadership in carrying out God’s plan, foreshadowing the necessity of a united spiritual authority.

verses.text: 'Is not the LORD your God with you? Has he not given you rest on every side? For he has delivered the inhabitants of the land into your hand, and the land is subdued before the LORD and his people.'
verses.comment: David reminds the people of God's fulfilled promises and peace, encouraging confidence in continued obedience and worship.

verses.text: 'Now set your heart and soul to seek the LORD your God. Arise and build the sanctuary of the LORD God, to bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD and the holy vessels of God into the house built for the name of the LORD.'
verses.comment: The exhortation to 'set your heart and soul' recalls the call to wholehearted devotion (Deut. 6:5). The gathering of the ark and holy vessels in the house for God anticipates fullness of worship, hinting at both symbolic and real presence of God among His people.
